dialog: Subtitles by <font color"ff0000">explosiveskull</font> Resync by <font color"00ffff">GoldenBeard</font> You Red Welby?
Are you in charge of renting the three billboards out on Drinkwater Road?
I didn't know we had any billboards on...
Nobody uses it since the freeway got put in.
We got three billboards out there.
Nobody's put nothing up there since 1986.
How much to rent all three of them out for the year?
On a road that no one goes down unless they got lost or they're retards...
Well, since what I say goes these days down at the Ebbing Advertising Desk...
I'm gonna strike you a real good deal.
What's the law on what you can and cannot say on a billboard?
Nothing defamatory, and you can't say "fuck", "piss" or "cunt". That right?
Well, I think I'll be all right then.
And here's what they are to say.
Why don't you write up a contract betwixt us while you're at it.
Make sure nobody rents them billboards out from under me.
I guess you're Angela Hayes's mother.
How long before you get them put up?

âª As I was walking down the streets of Laredo âª âª As I walked down to Laredo one day âª âª I spied a young cowboy all wrapped in white linen âª âª All wrapped in white linen and cold as the clay âª Hey, what the hell is this?
Listen, you fucking beaner, I'd better start getting some straight answers.
Don't I know your face from some place?
I could arrest you right now...
That's being bad against the environment laws.
Well, before you do that, Officer Dixon, how about you have a look at that first billboard over there?
And then we can have ourself a conversation about the motherfucking environment.
I'm in the middle of my goddamn Easter dinner.
I know, Chief, and I'm sorry for calling you at home and all, but...
I think we got kind of a problem.
Did you put up those billboards yet?
Go, girl. You go fuck those cops up.
What the fuck do you think you're doing, Welby?
You didn't think there would be legal ramifications?
Do you want me to explain?
Ain't contravening no laws on any fucking thing.
And where did you check all this out?
Book called Suck My Ass, It's None Of Your Business.
How long has this person, or persons, rented these billboards out for?
How long has she actually paid for?
I ain't at liberty to divulge that kind of information, Chief.
Ain't at liberty to divulge that kind of information, Chief.
Do you really wanna fuck with the Ebbing Police Department, Red?
No crime has been committed here.
Defamation of character ain't a crime?
Not if she's simply asking a question.
Don't call me an idiot, Dixon!
I didn't call you an idiot, I asked if you was an idiot.
Why in the hell you keep that man on?
He's a good man at heart.
He tortured a guy in custody, Bill.
There was no real evidence to support that.
Hey, boy. Think I wouldn't take you out right here on Main Street, Red?
Thought you only took out black dudes, Dixon.
You ever fucking touch me, motherfucker...
Nobody ever goes down that road anyways.
Don't be nervous, is the main thing.
Don't look into the camera, obviously.
So, Mildred Hayes, why did you put up these billboards?
My daughter, Angela, was abducted, raped and murdered seven months ago along this selfsame stretch of road.
What you watching, Momma? Stupid news?
Seems to me the local police department is too busy torturing black folks to be bothered doing anything about solving actual crime.
I thought these billboards might concentrate their minds some.
I don't know what the police are doing.
...daughter's burnt body is lying six feet underground.
They're eating Krispy Kremes and busting eightyearolds for skating around parking lots.
And Chief Willoughby, why single him out?
And the buck stops at Willoughby?
Looks like we got a war on our hands.
I'd do anything to catch the guy who did it, Mrs. Hayes.

But when the DNA don't match no one who's ever been arrested, and when the DNA don't match any other crime nationwide, and when there wasn't a single eyewitness from the time she'd left your house to the time we found her, right now there ain't too much more we can do.
Could pull blood from every man and boy in this town over the age of eight.
There's civil rights laws prevents that, Mrs. Hayes.
What if he was just passing through town?
Every man in the country, then.
What if he was just passing through the country?
If it was me, I'd start up a database.
Every male baby what's born, stick them on it, and as soon as he done something wrong, crossreference it, make 100% certain it was a correct match, then kill him.
Yeah, well, there's definitely civil rights laws prevents that.
I'm doing everything I can to track him down.
I don't think those billboards is very fair.
The time it took you to get out here whining like a bitch, Willoughby, some other poor girl's probably being butchered right now.
But I'm glad you got your priorities straight, I'll say that for you.
I know it. Most everybody in town knows it.
And you still put up those billboards?
Well, they wouldn't be as effective after you croak.
If it ain't the instigator of this whole goddamn affair in the first place.
Playing pool against the town midget.
He's right, Red, you are playing pool against the town midget.
I always disliked you, ever since you was a snotty little child.
You still look like a snotty little child.
That's unfortunate. I always thought you was great.
Like you was some kind of goddamn communist and proud of it.
No, it's because I got red hair.
You know what they do to faggots down in Cuba, Welby?
No, what do they do to faggots down in Cuba, Dixon?
Which, it might surprise you to learn, I'm against.
I'm not sure if they do kill faggots down in Cuba, Dixon.
I know Cuba's human rights record's pretty deplorable when it comes to homosexuality, but killing them?
Are you sure you ain't thinking of Wyoming?
Always gotta be the smartass, Jesus.
Hey, look at me. Look at me.
I'm talking nice to you now, aren't I?
Shouldn't have this be the only thing he thinks about, last months left to him.
I'm up next. You old ladies quit yakking.
I saw you on TV the other day.
I mean, you know, you came across really good in the things that you were saying.
I didn't think you came across real good.
I thought you came across as a stupidass.
Ain't it about time you got home to your momma, Dixon?
No, it ain't time I go home to my momma.
I told her I was gonna be out till 12:00, actually.
That's me versus you, Mildred. Uhhuh.
I think that midget wants to get in my pants.
Mildred. I'm sorry to be calling on you so late, but, uh...
I must say, Robbie has been the consummate host.
Despite his having had, as he was just telling me somewhat of a tricky day at school.
Just some of the guys on the team giving me crap.
Which is what I've come to have a word with you about.
I know how hard it's been for you, Mildred, this past year.
And if there is ever anything that you need, we will be there for you.
But the town also knows what kind of a man William Willoughby is.
And the town is dead set against these billboards of yours.
Took a poll, did you, Father?
If you hadn't stopped coming to church, you'd have a little bit more understanding of the depth of people's feelings.
More than a dozen people came to me on Sunday.
So, yes, I took a poll.
Everybody is with you about Angela.
Nobody is with you about this.
You know what I was thinking about today?
I was thinking about those street gangs they have down in Los Angeles, those Crips and those Bloods.
And I was thinking about that bunch of new laws they came up with in the 1980s, I think it was, to combat those street gangs, those Crips and those Bloods.

And, if I remember rightly, the gist of what those new laws were saying was, if you join one of these gangs, and you're running with them, and down the block one night, unbeknownst to you, one of your fellow Crips, or your fellow Bloods, shoot up a place, or stab a guy...
Well then, even though you may not know nothing about it and you were just standing on a street corner minding your own business, what these new laws said was you're still culpable.
You're still culpable by the very act of having joined those Crips and those Bloods in the first place.
Which got me thinking, Father, that whole type of situation is kinda like you church boys, ain't it?
You got your colors, you got your clubhouse.
You're, for want of a better word, a gang.
And if you were upstairs smoking a pipe and reading your Bible while one of your fellow gang members is downstairs fucking an altar boy, well...
Father, just like those Crips, and just like those Bloods, you're culpable.
Because you joined the gang, man.
I don't care if you never did shit, you never saw shit, you never heard shit, you join the gang, you're culpable.

And when a person is culpable to altarboyfucking, or any kinda boyfucking, because I know you guys didn't really narrow that down, then you kinda forfeit the right to come into my house and say anything about me or my life, or my daughter, or my billboards.
So why don't you just finish up your tea there, Father, and get the fuck outta my kitchen.
But thanks for coming up anyway, Father.
Ah, like I got cancer in a major organ.
Well, I just want you to know we're all on your side about this Mildred Hayes thing.
If I have to hear that one more fucking time...
I can't waste my life waiting.
Stop reading fucking comic books and get me the file on the Hayes case.
Angela Hayes case or the Mildred Hayes case?
There is no Mildred Hayes case.
We've had two official complaints about those billboards, so, actually...
There's a lady with a funny eye and a fat dentist.
Get me the file on the Angela Hayes case.
Lay off that Welby guy, will you?
Kick your momma's fucking teeth in.
Who told you I was laying on him anyway?
What the fuck are you talking about?
And I'm trying to fucking concentrate.
I don't know what it is.
It feels like it's kinda waggling.
Well, if it's waggling, it's gonna have to come out.
Ain't you gonna take a look at it first?
It's gonna have to come out.
Can I get a little Novocaine there, doc?
Give it a couple of minutes.
There's a lot of good friends of Bill Willoughby in this town.
Then why don't you tell those good friends of Bill Willoughby to tell him to go do his fucking job, fat boy.
You didn't happen to pay a visit to the dentist today, did you?
So it wasn't you who drilled a little hole in one of big fat Geoffrey's big fat thumbnails, no?
You drilled a hole in the dentist?
I thought it was kinda funny myself, but he wants to press charges, so we're gonna have to bring you in, I'm afraid.
So how's it all going in the niggertorturing business, Dixon?
If you wanna know, I didn't torture nobody.
What's the matter with you, saying that goddamn stuff on TV?
She doesn't know about the torturing?
No. She's against that kinda thing.
I said, "You can't say 'niggertorturing' no more.
"You gotta say personsofcolortorturing." Isn't that right, Chief?
I think I'll be able to take care of Mrs. Hayes on my own from here on, Jason.
If you got rid of every cop with vaguely racist leanings, you'd have three cops left, and all of them are gonna hate the fags.
So what are you gonna do, you know?
Why did you drill a hole through poor fat Geoffrey's thumbnail?
He drilled a hole through his own self.
Did he say I did it?
I guess it's his word against mine, then, huh?
Kinda like in all those rape cases you hear about.
Except, this time, the chick ain't losing.
It ain't really about winning or losing, though, is it, Mildred?
You think I care about who wins or loses between the two of youse?
You think I care about dentists?

What I do care about, or what I'm interested in is tying you up in court so long that your hours at the gift shop be so shot to shit that you ain't gonna have a penny to pay for another month's billboards.
I got some dough put away.
But what I heard was you had to sell off your exhusband's tractortrailer to even pay for this month's billboards, that right?
How is old Charlie, by the way?
He still shacked up with that pretty little intern works down at the zoo?
Still shacked up with some chick smells of shit.
I don't know if the zoo's got anything to do with it.
What's Charlie think about these billboards of yours, an excop like Charlie?
His word against yours, though, right?
Charlie don't know about them, does he?
He's kinda paying for them, though.
Yeah, well, I wasn't talking about dogs, was I?
Great, the good old "Raped While Dying" ride home.
If there was two seconds in a day when I wasn't thinking about how she died...

"Think about it some more, why don't you?" As much as a person might have tried to avoid the details of what happened because he didn't think it would do any good, and he couldn't bear it, it's also good to be informed in 20foothigh font the precise details of her last moments.
That it wasn't enough that she was raped and it wasn't enough that she died, no.
I gave you the police reports.
I'm depressed enough as it fucking is.
You ain't going out again tonight, are you?
Denise and I are gonna grab a couple of beers.
Why don't you just ask to borrow the car?
I will give you money for a taxi if you ask nice and don't call me a bitch.
Why make me ask if you weren't gonna let me?
And because you've been smoking pot all day.
Drove drunk when we were kids.
Did you drive drunk with us in the car when we were kids?
When he was in the middle of beating the shit out of me.
Which we've only got your word about!
Why are you never on my side?
I'm always on your side when you're not being a cunt!
There will be no more "cunts" in this house.
Are you gonna let me borrow the car or what?
Why don't you just walk, Angela?
I hope I get raped on the way!
Gonna need to keep you in a few days, Bill.
You shouldn't be coughing up blood.
Yeah, I kinda guessed that, Doc.
I'll swing by in the morning.
I guess I'll go get your coat, huh?
Well, you know I ain't staying.
Kid has got Rice fucking Krispies in his fucking hair.
What's going on with these fucking billboards?
Why don't you explain it to me?
I wanted certain people's minds kept on certain people's jobs, is all.
Hadn't heard from them in seven goddamn months.
I've heard an awful lot from them since I put them billboards up.
You think this has focused their minds? Mmm?
It's focused their minds on how exactly are they gonna fuck you up.
The more you keep a case in the public eye, the better your chances are of getting it solved.
About the same as a tractortrailer.
What the fuck are you laughing at?
Laughed at by a guy with fucking cereal in his hair.
Why don't you invite her in?
Save leaving her sitting out there.
Oh! Um, I kinda need to use the bathroom, but if it's inconvenient...
Actually, it is inconvenient, isn't it?
It's the first door down the hall.
Sure? I feel like I'm intruding.
Look, you said what you came to say.
So why don't you go get zoo girl and get the hell out of my house, all right?
Um, actually, zoowise, they were letting people go at the zoo, unfortunately, and it was a case of "last in, first out". So...
Unfortunately the zoo had to let me go.
But they were looking for people down at the horse rides for the disableds.
So I'm working down there now, looking after the disableds' horses.
I wasn't gonna say a word.
You don't think I don't wish it had never happened?
You don't think I don't wish she was still here?
Billboards ain't gonna bring her back, Mildred.
I'm such a shitty dad and you're such a great mom.
So how come a week before she died she's asking if she can move in with me at my place?
Couldn't stand you bitching and fighting with each other no more.
I said, "Stay, your mom loves you." Now I wish I hadn't.
Oh, come on, not Donald Sutherland again.
What is this, frickin' Donald Sutherland season?
This is the one where his little girl dies.
Always a plus in a movie.
Talking of dead kids, what's happening with the billboard lady?
Oh, that kooz won't listen to reason.
She's tough as an old boot.
Why don't you just fuck her over through her friends then?
You know, why don't you fuck her friends over?
She got any friends you can fuck over?
Don't say "what", Dixon, when she comes in calling you a fuckhead.
You do not allow a member of the public to call you a fuckhead in the station house!
I'm taking care of it in my own way.
Now get out of my ass.
What can I do for you today?
I asked the judge not to give her bail on account of her previous marijuana violations, and the judge said "sure." You fucking prick!
You do not call an officer of the law a fucking prick in his own station house, Mrs. Hayes.
What's with the new attitude, Dixon?
Take them down, you hear me?
No kid can leave this goddamn blanket at any goddamn time.
And every single one of these dolls and these teddy bears has got to be hooked up.
Now, your momma and I, although it won't look like it, we'll be watching every goddamn move you make.
So the most important thing while we are watching you is that you do not leave this blanket.
Next most important thing, you do not at any stage allow the fishing rods to stick into you or your sister's eyeballs, as this would be counterproductive to the entire operation.
Because there ain't no God, the whole world's empty, and it doesn't matter what we do to each other?
How come you came up here outta nowhere looking so pretty?
You ain't trying to make me believe in reincarnation or something, are you?
Because you're pretty, but you ain't her.
She got killed, and now she's dead forever.
I do thank you for coming though.
If I had some food I'd give it to you.
All I got is some Doritos.
They might kill you, they're kind of pointy.
Yeah, so I, uh, just happened to be looking over our contract that we drew up back that time.
I realized that although payment is to be made on the first day of each month, the first payment you paid was actually a deposit.
So, actually, in point of fact, you're actually behind in your payments now, by, yeah, a month.
It's what the contract says, looking over it and all.
When you need this next payment by, Red?
When you can't trust the lawyers and the advertising men, what the hell's America coming to, huh?
We're a little bit busy at the moment, if that's okay.
I know you were real anxious about talking to Mrs. Hayes this morning...
No need to be, because you won't believe it!
A little Mexican delivery boy just dropped in with this.
It's $5,000! And guess what the note says?
It says to pay for the rental on Mrs. Hayes's billboards.
Did you see what company he was from?
What kind of uniform did he have on?
Well, he just looked like one of those fat little Mexican boys.
Yeah, Pamela, you did real good.
Says, "This here money is to go towards the fund "for Mildred Hayes's billboards, "because she ain't the only one 'round here "who hates the pigs.
Signed, a friend." I guess you can't be too picky about who your friends are these days, huh?
I guess I'll be needing a receipt off you there, Red, you know, saying the price of next month is paid in full and all.
No. She's just got a little migraine, is all.
Now, no more chitchat outta you two, okay?
Can we stay home from school again tomorrow, Daddy?
We'll see what your mommy says in the morning, darling.
Eyes closed and go to sleep, okay?
You don't smell like puke, which is good.
But it's still your turn to clean the horseshit outta the stable, you know.
I'm gonna have those fucking horses shot!
I'll do it, you lazy bitch.
That was a real nice day.
That was a real nice fuck.
You got a real nice cock, Mr. Willoughby.
"You got a real nice cock, Mr. Willoughby." I think I heard that in a Shakespeare one time.
My darling Anne, there's a longer letter in the dresser drawer I've been writing for the last week or so.
That one covers us and my memories of us and how much I've always loved you.
This one just covers tonight, and more importantly, today.
Tonight I've gone out to the horses to end it.
I cannot say sorry for the act itself, although I know that for a short time you will be angry at me or even hate me for it.
This is not a case of, "I came in this world alone "and I'm going out of it alone," or anything dumb like that.
I did not come in this world alone, my mom was there.
And I am not going out of it alone, because you are there, drunk on the couch, making Oscar Wilde cock jokes.
No, this is a case, in some senses, of bravery.
Not the bravery of facing a bullet down.
The next few months of pain would be far harder than that small flash.

No, it's the bravery of weighing up the next few months of still being with you, still waking up with you, of playing with the kids against the next few months of seeing in your eyes how much my pain is killing you, how my weakened body, as it ebbs away, and you tend to it, are your final and lasting memories of me.

Your final memories of me will be us at the riverside and that dumb fishing game, which I think they cheated at, and me inside of you and you on top of me and barely a fleeting thought of the darkness yet to come.
A whole day of not thinking about it.
Dwell on this day, baby, because it was the best day of my life.
Kiss the girls for me, and know that I've always loved you, and maybe I'll see you again if there's another place.
And if there ain't, well, it's been heaven knowing you.
What the hell's going on around here?
I'd better get out there, say something to them.
You ain't gonna faint again, are you?
I know that the best thing, the only thing to honor that man's memory right now is to go to work.
Is to be a good cop.
To walk in his shoes and do what he did every day of his life.
See, Red, I got issues with white folks too.
Reports, sadly, have come in overnight, that Chief William Willoughby of Ebbing, Missouri took his own life early this morning in the grounds of his home.
This report just in from Gabriella Forrester.
Tragedy came calling today upon this quiet family home outside Ebbing, Missouri, belonging to Chief Willoughby, his wife, Anne, their two young daughters, Polly and Jane.
What appears to be a selfinflicted gunshot wound brought life to an end for Chief Willoughby, a man highlyrespected in Ebbing for his diligence and service to the community.
What led him to take his life in the early hours of this morning, it is too early to speculate.
Could it simply have been the pressures of the job?
Or could it have something to do with a story we ran here just two weeks ago of these billboards, and the woman who put them there, Mildred Hayes?
You know who threw that can?
You know who threw that can?
And what can I do for you today, sir?
Kinda like "hard of hearing", but it's actually "hard of reading".
Like a play on words or something, huh?
I've been sent to take over from Chief Willoughby in light of last night's unfortunate event.
You have got to be fucking kidding me!
Do you have any documentation to prove that, sir?
You really wanna see my documentation, fucker?
Make him show it to you.
None of you cracker motherfuckers got no work to do?
What happened to your hand, Officer Dixon?
Oh, I just kinda banged it up a little bit while I was throwing some guy out a fucking window.
They never taught me that one at the academy.
Which fucking academy you go to?
How are things coming along on that Angela Hayes case?
How's things coming along on the mind your own fucking business case?
How are things coming along on the hand me your gun and your badge?
Hand me your gun and your badge.
Hey, listen, I can't find my badge.
Dropped it when I was doing that window guy.
Just get the fuck out of my station house, man.
I think I just got fired.
Fired or suspended, I'm not sure which.
Anything I can help you with, just give me a holler.
Only from the TV and the radio.
How much these here "Welcome to Missouri" rabbits go for?
Guess he ain't seven bucks now.
What did you come in here for?
What did I come in here for?
Maybe I'm a good friend of Willoughby's, how about that?
Maybe I was a friend of your daughter or something.
You know, maybe I was the one who fucked her while she was dying.
I saw her picture in the paper there.
You owe me seven fucking dollars for the rabbit.
Guess you'll have to get it off me next time I'm passing through.
You don't know how glad I am to see you.
That guy was trying to scare me.
I wouldn't have said you scare easy.
What can I do for you, ma'am?
My husband left this for you before he shot himself in the head last night.
Surely this is the perfect ending for you, isn't it?
Proof those billboards of yours were successful, a dead policeman?
Are you blaming this on me?
I'm not blaming this on you.
I just came to give you the letter.
Now my little girls are out in the car, so I'd better not stay and chat.
I'm not quite sure what we're gonna do for the rest of the day.
It's hard to know what to do the day your husband kills himself.
It's hard to know what to do.
Dear Mildred, Dead Man Willoughby here.
Firstly, I wanted to apologize for dying without catching your daughter's killer.
It's a source of great pain to me, and it would break my heart to think you thought I didn't care.

There are just some cases where you never catch a break, then five years down the line some guy hears some other guy bragging about it in a bar room or a jail cell and the whole thing is wrapped up through sheer stupidity.
I hope that might be true for Angela, I really do.
Second, I gotta admit, Mildred, the billboards were a great fucking idea.
They were like a chess move.

And although they had absolutely nothing to do with my dying, I'm sure that everyone in town will assume that they did, which is why, for Willoughby's countermove, I decided to pay the next month's rent on them.
I thought it would be funny, you having to defend them another whole month after they've stuck me in the ground.
The joke is on you, Mildred, ha ha, and I hope they do not kill you.
So good luck with all that, and good luck with everything else too.
I hope and I pray that you get him.
Well, you want me to go down and talk to them?
No, I don't want you to go down and talk to them.
Somebody sending their goddamn mother down to talk to the goddamn police?
To say to give you your job back.
Get rid of that black guy.
Ain't gonna listen to some guy's mother asking them to get rid of some black guy.
Things have moved on in the South.
Will they give you some money for being laid off and all?
I don't know what the compensation scheme is for when you throw a guy out of a window, Ma.
Guess I should have looked into that beforehand.
Not counting the five years at the academy.
Six, if you count the year you were held back.
Off to see your fancy woman?
I don't got a fancy woman.
I'll blow your goddamn head off, that's what.
Oh, did you hear the news?
That Dixon guy threw that Welby guy out of his window this morning.
Get the other one from the house.
Shouldn't I call the fire department?
What the hell are you doing?
Can I ask you a couple of questions?
You can ask me all the questions you want, you take me down and arrest me.
I'm not gonna arrest you, Mrs. Hayes.
I got nothing to arrest you for.
We ain't all the enemy, you know.
What are you gonna do, Mildred?
Yeah, I'm gonna crucify the motherfuckers.
Ooh, then those motherfuckers better watch out, all right?

And as sad as the spectacle of these burned out billboards might be, in light of the death of Chief Willoughby, this reporter for one wonders if this finally puts an end to the strange saga of the three billboards...
This doesn't put an end to shit, you fucking retard, this is just the fucking start!
Why don't you put that on your Good Morning Missouri fucking Wake Up broadcast, bitch!
I see on the TV there were a bunch of fires lit outside of town last night.
Back when I was a cop I would have been interested in who set those fires, because, technically, that's arson, but as I'm no longer employed by those people, I don't really give a goddamn.
Anne Willoughby just dropped in a letter that Bill wrote you before he died.
I haven't read it, it's not my letter.
Oh, well, listen, I'll come right down.
Um, I'll be there in like 15 minutes.
Not such a great idea, things as they stand, Jason.
You still got your keys to the station house, though, right?
Why don't you come and pick it up after everyone's gone home?
I can leave it on your desk for you.
Actually, yeah, then when you're done, you can just leave the keys, you know, save us picking them up later.
I'm dead now, sorry about that.
There's something I wanted to say to you that I never really said when I was alive.
I think you've got the makings of being a really good cop, Jason.
Because deep down you're a decent man.
I know you don't think I think that, but I do, dipshit.
I do think you're too angry, though.
And I know it's all since your dad died, and you had to go look after your mom.
But as long as you hold on to so much hate, then I don't think you're ever gonna become what I know you wanna become.
Because you know what you need to become a detective?
And I know you're gonna wince when I say this...
But what you need to become a detective is love.
Because through love comes calm, and through calm comes thought.
And you need thought to detect stuff sometimes, Jason.
You don't even need a gun.
And you definitely don't need hate.
